I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Country Programming Mission in April 2005, the Government of the Lao 
People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) confirmed the request for Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) technical assistance (TA) to support capacity building for gender mainstreaming.1 The TA 
is included in the 2005 TA program in Lao PDR country strategy and program update (2006–
2008).2 The TA Fact-Finding Mission3 visited Lao PDR from 21 to 30 April 2005 and held 
discussions  with  the  Government  on  the  impact,  outcome,  activities,  implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services. 
The Government confirmed the mission’s aide memoire on 29 June 2005. The TA framework is 
in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES4 
2.  Agriculture accounts for 50% of the Lao PDR’s gross domestic product and employs 
over 80% of the total labor force, mainly for subsistence. The Government recognizes that 
modernizing and strengthening the agriculture sector is critical to its goal of poverty reduction. 
Rural  women  play  vital  roles  as  farmers  and  agroprocessors,  raisers  of  small  livestock, 
harvesters of nontimber forest products, producers of handicrafts and other nonfarm products, 
and  traders.  Gender  roles  in  agriculture  can  vary  considerably,  often  related  to  ethnicity, 
location, type of farming system, use of technology, and other factors. Gender roles are also 
changing rapidly as more farming households diversify into cash crops, as communities relocate 
from upland areas to amalgamated villages closer to roads and towns, and as government 
policies change the allocation of rural land and influence farming practices.  
 
3.  As it has direct bearing on poverty reduction, gender equality is one of the intersectoral 
priorities of the Government’s National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy (NGPES). The 
NGPES gender strategy for poverty reduction stipulates several measures to better support 
women farmers’ productive capacity and local knowledge. These include (i) inclusion of women 
in project activities, (ii) equal participation of women in extension services and training, (iii) use 
of gender-related indicators to monitor projects, (iv) increase in the number of female provincial 
and district staff and extension workers, and (v) gender focal points in villages to promote 
improved agricultural practices.  
 
4.  To support, promote, and protect the benefits and rights of women in all aspects, the 
Government  established  the  National  Commission  for  the  Advancement  of  Women  (Lao-
NCAW) in April 2003. To help Lao-NCAW effectively carry out its mandate, subcommissions for 
the advancement of women (Sub-CAWs) were set up within 11 ministries and offices, including 
the ministries of agriculture and forestry, education, foreign affairs, industry and handicraft, 
information  and  culture,  justice,  labor  and  social  welfare,  national  security,  public  health; 
Committee for Planning and Investment; and the Prime Minister’s Office. Lao-NCAW is currently 
drafting the national strategy for the advancement of women (2006–2010) with sector and 
thematic  inputs  from  the  Sub-CAWs  and  their  secretariats.  Once  the  national  strategy  is 
approved, the Sub-CAWs are expected to facilitate its implementation in the respective line 
ministries and offices.

5.  The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) recently prepared a cross-sector 
project to achieve gender equality and poverty reduction: Gender Empowerment for Poverty 
Reduction: Building Capacity for Stronger Policy and Practice.5 The project will support key 
institutions  including  Lao-NCAW,  Lao  Women's  Union,  Gender  Resource  Information  and 
Development Center, Committee for Planning and Investment, and Ministry of Finance. The 
Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) is identified as a model ministry for gender and 
poverty mainstreaming. The TA was prepared in close consultation with the UNDP project 
formulation team. Because of its horizontal and vertical linkage to the UNDP project, the TA is 
expected to produce wide-ranging results and multiplier impact. Close coordination will be 
maintained during TA implementation.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  In  accordance  with  the  NGPES  gender  strategy  and  draft  MAF  strategy  for  the 
advancement of women,6 the purpose of the TA is to reduce gender disparities and increase 
women’s productivity in agriculture, and thus reduce poverty and promote growth. The specific 
TA objectives are to (i) build gender-responsive institutional structures and systems at MAF, (ii) 
strengthen  the  capacity  of  MAF  officials  and  selected  provincial  and  district  office  staff  to 
incorporate gender dimensions in MAF's policies, strategies, programs, and projects; and (iii) 
deliver gender-sensitive and pro-poor agricultural extension services. Critical findings and major 
recommendations of the special evaluation study are on capacity development7 have been 
reflected in the design of the TA, including the focus on the diagnostic stage and human 
resource management through a structured and sequential capacity development program. 
 
7.  The key TA outputs will include (i) improved institutional setup, systems, procedures, 
and medium-term framework to effectively integrate and monitor gender mainstreaming at MAF; 
(ii) increased gender awareness and gender mainstreaming capacity and skills of key personnel 
in the agriculture sector; and (iii) improved women’s access to agricultural extension services.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  Many factors limit women’s productivity in agricultural production. The constraints are 
interrelated and need to be addressed systematically. Thus, the TA will focus on three major 
constraints: (i) institutional and procedural factors, such as lack of appropriate systems and of 
clarity in relation to functions, roles, and responsibilities for gender mainstreaming; (ii) human 
resource and capacity factors, including lack of awareness, knowledge, and skills on the part of 
staff in MAF and provincial and district agriculture and forestry offices on gender issues; and (iii) 
access and control factors, such as the absence of gender-responsive support services and 
service delivery. By addressing these three factors concurrently, the TA will develop an effective 
and sustainable structure and environment to enhance the role of women in the agriculture 
sector and empower them, thus reducing poverty and inequality.  
                                                 
5  Preliminary activities will commence in late 2005, and the main phase will be implemented from 2006 to 2008. 
6  Currently under preparation, addressing (i) employment creation, (ii) expansion of income-generating opportunities 
to reduce poverty, and (iii) enhancing knowledge relating to agricultural production.  
7  ADB. 2004. Special Evaluation Study on Capacity Development Assistance of the Asian Development Bank to the 
Lao People's Democratic Republic. Manila.

3
1.  Creating an Institutional Framework for Gender Mainstreaming 
9.  Under this component, MAF’s organizational and personnel management systems and 
procedures will be assessed, and recommendations made for improvements. First, an inventory 
of  MAF  human  resources,  in  the  national  office,  a  pilot  province  (to  be  identified  later  in 
accordance  with  criteria  to  be  developed  during  TA  implementation),  and  districts  will  be 
prepared. Existing individual job descriptions will be collected. Subsequently with participatory 
methods, the current roles and responsibilities of MAF departments, provincial agriculture and 
forestry offices, and district agriculture and forestry extension offices will be examined with 
regard to gender mainstreaming. The review will focus on how to integrate gender perspectives 
into MAF’s overall planning cycle and how to track the link between plans, human resources, 
and  budgets.8  The  TA  will  help  establish  systems  and  procedures  for  the  technical  line 
departments to screen all new policies, programs, and projects from a gender perspective. A 
new gender mainstreaming framework will be integrated into standard MAF operations. The 
action  plan  in  the  forthcoming  MAF  Strategy  for  the  Advancement  of  Women  will  be 
implemented in accordance with this framework.  
 
10.  The NGPES gender strategy calls for improving the gender and ethnic balance of all 
staffing in line ministries. The exclusion of women from participation in government decision 
making means that gender-based needs are not properly considered and addressed, and that 
sector policies and programs are incomplete. The TA will examine the current situation in MAF 
and make recommendations to reduce gender disparities in recruitment, transfers, promotions, 
and career development. The TA will also explore means to increase the number of female 
agricultural extension workers in both the short and medium term.  
 
11.  Effective planning will require accurate and updated information on gender relations and 
gender disparities. Gender-disaggregated data has been collected by MAF; however the data 
has not been analyzed to reveal gender disparities nor has it subsequently been used in the 
planning process. In cooperation with the standardized data collection format under the Gender 
Empowerment  for  Poverty  Reduction  Project  (para.  5),  the  TA  will  facilitate  MAF's  use  of 
gender-disaggregated data for application in the planning cycle.  
 
2.  Building Capacity for Gender Mainstreaming 
12.  By providing training and capacity-building support for MAF, this component aims to link 
the existing human resources, staff job requirements, and department objectives, to build a 
more gender-responsive institution. The inventory prepared and the roles and responsibilities of 
the departments identified under component 1 will form the basis for the activities. Training will 
be provided to fill the gap between functions required for gender mainstreaming and current 
staff knowledge and skills. The TA will utilize existing gender training materials available within 
MAF. 
 
13.  The MAF staff trained on gender issues will form a network and be strengthened to 
become a key in-house training resource. Under the TA, these in-house trainers will work with 
the external specialists to conduct training programs. All MAF senior staff will be trained on 
gender awareness and basic gender issues in agriculture. MAF Sub-CAW Secretariat members

Reduction Project.

4   
and department gender focal points will receive intensive training to enable them to function 
effectively as advocates and facilitators for gender mainstreaming.  
 
3.  Gender-Sensitive and Pro-Poor Agricultural Extension Services 
14.  Gender sensitivity is one of the principles in the comprehensive extension strategy in the 
Lao PDR, which introduced the community-based and participatory village extension system.9 
The strategy acknowledges that men and women play different roles in agricultural production, 
and face different constraints and opportunities in accessing resources and services. In line with 
the new mandate of the government extension service, this TA component will elaborate and 
implement  the  gender-integrated,  gender-sensitive,  and  pro-poor  extension  service  delivery 
models to meet the needs of target beneficiaries. Specific attention will be paid to the varied 
gender roles in agriculture, which are often related to ethnicity, location, type of farming system, 
use of technology, etc.  
 
4.  Pilot Activities for Capacity Building 
15.  This component will apply and test the gender mainstreaming framework in the field and 
support building provincial and district staff capacity through on-the-job training. In the new 
extension service structure, provincial and district staff are to be trained to be farming system 
extension workers, and the latter are expected to regularly interact with local communities, 
village  extension  workers,  and  farmers  to  understand  their  expressed  needs.  Under  this 
component provincial agriculture and forestry extension centers and district agriculture and 
forestry extension offices will prepare action plans translating the sector gender mainstreaming 
objectives and strategic priorities into local pilot activities. Such activities may include village 
participatory  planning,  extension  services  targeted  to  specific  subjects,  and  livelihood 
improvement and skill development support.10 Detailed activities will be developed through a 
participatory process approach.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $471,000 equivalent, of which $250,000 is the 
foreign  exchange  cost  and  $221,000  equivalent  the  local  currency  cost.  ADB  will  provide 
$400,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and $150,000 equivalent of the 
local currency cost. TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The 
Government will finance the balance of the local currency cost, equivalent to $71,000, in kind 
through the provision of counterpart staff, office accommodation, and other related services and 
facilities. Cost estimates and the financing plan are presented in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  MAF will be the Executing Agency for the TA; the head of MAF's Sub-CAW Secretariat 
will be the TA director. MAF's Sub-CAW Secretariat members will be the counterparts of the TA 
consultant team, and will liaise with the gender focal points of the departments of planning and 
personnel, the permanent secretary's office, and the national agriculture and forestry extension

5
service, for implementation of the relevant TA components. Provincial agriculture and forestry 
extension centers and district agriculture and forestry extension offices will be in charge of 
implementation of the pilot activities. The chair of MAF's Sub-CAW (vice minister, MAF and 
commissioner of Lao-NCAW) will provide overall guidance and oversee implementation of all TA 
activities. The TA will be implemented in close coordination with the project management team 
for the Gender Empowerment for Poverty Reduction Project and will report the TA’s major 
achievements  and  milestone  outputs  to  the  Central  Project  Advisory  Board  of  the  same 
project.11 The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations’ forthcoming capacity-
building project12 will support, on a parallel basis, the development of a ministry-wide gender 
mainstreaming policy and implementation plan. The TA will take a process approach with 
phased  planning  and  execution  of  each  component.  Periodic  monitoring,  feedback,  and 
evaluation will be carried out as an integral part of the TA; and the findings will be fed back for 
the design of subsequent capacity-building activities.  
 
18.  The TA, to be implemented over 18 months from January 2006 to June 2007, will require 
25  person-months  of  consulting  services:  10  person-months  of  international  consulting  in 
institutional development and planning, participatory consultation and systemic learning, and 
gender analysis; 15 person-months of domestic consulting in human resource development and 
training and agricultural extension services. Appendix 3 provides the outline terms of reference. 
The consultants will submit inception, midterm, final, and quarterly progress reports to ADB.  
 
19.  ADB will select and engage the consultants in accordance with the Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants by the Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. ADB’s standard quality- and 
cost-based selection method will be used, and technical proposals invited from short-listed 
consulting  firms  will  be  in  ADB’s  simplified  formats.  Equipment  for  the  consultant  will  be 
financed by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Equipment procured 
under the TA will become the property of the Government upon completion of the TA. 
 
20.  The TA outputs will be presented and shared at MAF through meetings and seminars 
organized  by  the  MAF  Sub-CAW  Secretariat.  The  outcome  and  lessons  learned  will  be 
disseminated  nationwide13  and  posted  on  ADB’s  website.  The  Gender  Empowerment  for 
Poverty Reduction Project will synthesize all activities and develop a gender mainstreaming tool 
kit for the Lao PDR, for future scaling up and replication by other ministries and sectors. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Lao People's Democratic Republic for Capacity Building for Gender 
Mainstreaming in Agriculture, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                 
11  Comprising the representatives from Lao Women’s Union, NCAW Secretariat, Prime Minister’s Office, Committee 
for Planning and Investment, MAF, and the UNDP national project director. The advisory board meets once a year.  
12  Strengthening  the  Policy,  Strategy,  and  Project  Formulation  and  Management  Capacity  of  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture and Forestry, to be implemented 2006–2007. Terms of Reference for the TA consultants have been 
developed to ensure no duplication of activities to be supported by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the 
United Nations. 
13  Collaborative and complementary activities will be planned with the Enhanced Advocacy on Gender Equality and 
Poverty Initiative under the Gender Empowerment for Poverty Reduction Project.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Institutional Development and Planning Specialist, and Team Leader (international, 
5 person-months, intermittent) 
1.  An institutional development and gender planning specialist will act as the team leader 
for the team of consultants engaged under the technical assistance (TA). The team leader will 
assume responsibilities for overall coordination with the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry 
(MAF) Sub-CAW Secretariat, MAF departmental gender focal points, the consultant team for the 
Gender Empowerment for Poverty Reduction Project, and relevant ongoing projects at MAF. 
The consultant’s tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Provide overall planning, coordination, and management of the TA and help the 
Sub-CAW Secretariat facilitate gender mainstreaming in agriculture. 
(ii)  Guide the activities of the consultants and manage administration and budget. 
(iii)  Formulate an overall TA work plan, and monitor and report periodically on the 
progress of activities through quarterly progress reports. 
(iv)  Review and assess the mandate, organizational structure, and capacity of MAF, 
provincial agriculture and forestry office (PAFOs), and district agriculture and 
forestry  extension  offices  (DAFEOs),  including  the  Department  of  Planning, 
Permanent Secretary's Office, Department of Personnel, National Agriculture and 
Forestry Extension Service, National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute, 
and MAF technical departments (agriculture, livestock and fisheries, forestry, and 
irrigation) with regard to integrating gender perspectives into their operations. 
(v)  In cooperation with human resource development and training specialist, assess 
the  job  descriptions  of  MAF,  PAFO,  and  DAFEO  staff,  and  assess  their 
effectiveness for implementing the necessary actions for mainstreaming gender. 
(vi)  Introduce a performance evaluation system.  
(vii)  Incorporate gender perspectives into the rationalized roles and responsibilities of 
MAF departments. 
(viii)  Design  a  system  under  MAF’s  institutional  objectives  and  mandate  to  fully 
integrate  gender  perspectives  in  its  operations  (gender  mainstreaming 
framework). 
(ix)  Ensure the logical linkage between the gender mainstreaming framework and 
human resource strategy and staff development and training plan to be prepared 
by the human resource development and training specialist. 
(x)  Help the Department of Personnel to formulate an affirmative action plan for the 
recruitment, transfer, career development, training, and promotion (with specific 
targets) of MAF women staff. 
(xi)  Prepare inception, midterm, final, and quarterly progress reports.  
 
B.  Participatory  Consultation  and  Systemic  Learning  Specialist  (international,  1 
person-month, intermittent) 
 
2.  A participatory consultation and systemic development specialist will work closely with 
the institutional development and planning specialist at the beginning of the TA to facilitate the 
managerial and human resource capacity review and assessment. Follow up assessment will 
be conducted during the midterm review of the TA. Responsibilities will include the following:

D.  Gender Analysis Specialist (international, 4 person-months, intermittent) 
4.  A specialist on gender analysis will work closely with the institutional development and 
planning specialist to strengthen MAF's institutional and human resource capacity to ensure that 
gender  perspectives  are  mainstreamed  in  policy,  strategy,  programs,  and  projects.  The 
consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Using  the  standardized  and  indicator  collection  format  under  the  Gender 
Empowerment  for  Poverty  Reduction  Project,  assess  the  current  status  of 
gender-disaggregated data collection systems at MAF and PAFOs. 
(ii)  Review the accuracy and usefulness of the gender-disaggregated data collected 
by various projects to date and assess the systems. 
(iii)  Through consultation with the MAF technical department staff, identify specific 
indicators with a view to using the data for the gender mainstreaming planning 
system. 
(iv)  Help  MAF  introduce  gender-sensitive  monitoring,  planning,  and  budgeting 
systems in cooperation with the gender-sensitive and pro-poor budget initiative 
under the Gender Empowerment for Poverty Reduction Project. 
(v)  Develop a simple project cycle monitoring and management system and logical 
framework to screen, monitor, and evaluate MAF projects, and provide on-the-job 
training on gender analysis on policies, strategies, and projects. 
(vi)  Prepare  manuals  and  guidelines  for  implementing  and  monitoring  gender 
mainstreaming actions taken by MAF’s key departments and PAFOs, and train 
the staff in use of these manuals and guidelines. 
(vii)  Prepare a report on the process of system development, outputs, results, and 
summaries to be included in the inception, midterm, final, and quarterly progress 
reports. 
(viii)  Carry out other tasks assigned by the institutional development and planning 
specialist and human resource development and training specialist.
